title: Brazil at risk of angering Arsenal as Gabriel Jesus is  set to start  in their World Cup qualifier against Argentina on Tuesday after Vinicius Jr was ruled out through injury
body_text:
Brazil at risk of angering Arsenal as Gabriel Jesus is 'set to start' in their World Cup qualifier against Argentina on Tuesday after Vinicius Jr was ruled out through injury
- Mikel Arteta has previously expressed his concerns over Gabriel Jesus' fitness
- But the Arsenal forward is 'set to start' Brazil's crunch game vs Argentina
- Aaron Ramsdale's dad has every right to support his son - It's All Kicking Off
Gabriel Jesus is reportedly 'set to start' in Brazil's crunch World Cup qualifier against Argentina on Tuesday, despite having been ruled out with a hamstring injury since October.
Arsenal will be sweating over his fitness, with Mail Sport previously reporting that Mikel Arteta and club medical staff had been concerned that the 26-year-old had not made a full recovery from the soft tissue injury that has sidelined him since their 2-1 victory against Sevilla in the Champions League last month.
While the Gunners had hoped that the forward would stay in London during the international break to continue his recovery, Brazil coach Fernando Diniz defied their wishes, calling him up to the international squad for their games against Colombia and Brazil.
While he was not included in the squad to play in their 2-1 defeat to Colombia on Friday, Brazilian outlet Globo Esporte claim, per The Sun, that he is 'set to start' against Argentina on Tuesday.
It comes as the Selecao have been left hampered by injuries to key forwards Neymar Jr and Vinicius Jr.
Arsenal will be sweating over the fitness of Gabriel Jesus with the forward reportedly 'set to start' for Brazil on Tuesday's crunch meeting with Argentina
Mikel Arteta had been keen not to rush the Arsenal forward back from a hamstring injury that has kept him sidelined since October
It's been an injury-hampered start to the season for the 26-year-old who came off the field during their 2-1 Champions League victory against Sevilla in October
Neymar suffered a torn ACL during his country's 2-0 defeat by Uruguay back in October which could rule him out for the remainder of the season.
Vinicius, meanwhile, gingerly left the field during Friday's loss against Colombia with a thigh injury and will reportedly return to Spain for further treatment.
Diniz could opt to call upon 17-year-old Real Madrid star Endrick, who came on in the 82nd minute of Friday's match. He could also look to Brighton's Joao Pedro as a replacement, with Richarlison also ruled out having undergone surgery last week.
Mail Sport also understands that Jesus, who has endured an injury stricken season so far, will be assessed by Brazil's medical team before the green light is given for him to play.
Arsenal's technical director Edu is in contact with the national side's staff over the fitness of the forward.
Jesus, who has scored four times in all competitions for Arsenal this season, has only featured in seven of their opening 12 Premier League matches, having been ruled out of their first three games with a knee injury.
One of those goals came during their victory against Sevilla, in which Jesus played 81 minutes before he left the field with a hamstring problem.
If deemed able to play, he could start in a front three alongside team-mate Gabriel Martinelli and Rodrygo.
Arteta had previously stressed that he didn't want to put a timeline on his return to full fitness, urging caution over rushing him back too fast.
'With him [Jesus], I’m honestly not going to give [a timeframe],' the Spanish manager said in a press conference ahead of his side's game against West Ham at the start of November.
He added: 'I did it once and got it totally wrong. We need to be cautious because we need to treat it in the right way.
'He’s already pushing everybody and wants to be back as quickly as possible, and we need him, so that’s great.'
But the Gunners boss will be sweating on the fitness of his forward should he start on Tuesday night.
Meanwhile, Diniz has also claimed that it was Jesus' decision to fly out to join the Brazil national team.
Jesus previously sustained a knee injury that saw him miss the first three games of the season
Arsenal staff in dialogue with the national side's medical team, who will assess his fitness before the tie
‘I trust the player and him being here. I talked to Gabriel and he didn’t come here without planning,' the Brazil coach said.
‘He said he is feeling good and was already doing things ten days before the first game and 15 days before the second game.
‘We thought it was an interesting risk to bring him here. He is in good condition.
‘We are doing things with great care. As soon as he arrived, we gave him a new MRI scan. We are treating him very carefully.
‘If he is in the right condition, he will be available against Argentina.'
